properties.areaDesc: South and Southeast Grand/West Central and Southwest Boulder/Gilpin/Clear Creek/Summit/North and West Park Counties Above 9000 Feet; South and East Jackson/Larimer/North and Northeast Grand/Northwest Boulder Counties Above 9000 Feet
properties.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued December 31 at 2:41PM MST until January 3 at 12:00AM MST by NWS Denver CO
properties.description:
...A ROUND OF SNOW AND HAZARDOUS WINTER TRAVEL CONDITIONS FOR THE
NORTHERN MOUNTAINS...

.Snow will develop in the northern mountains of Colorado
Wednesday morning and become widespread by early afternoon. The
snow will continue Wednesday night before tapering off slightly on
Thursday. Snowfall will increase again Thursday night before
ending Friday morning. Gusty winds will also produce blowing and
drifting snow and reduced visibilities in exposed areas and over
the higher mountain passes. The heaviest totals can be expected in
the mountains north of Rabbit Ears Pass with moderate snowfall
totals in the Front Range Mountains and Summit County.

* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 4 to 10
inches. Winds gusting as high as 60 mph.

* WHERE...Rocky Mountain National Park and the Medicine Bow
Range and The Mountains of Summit County, the Mosquito Range,
and the Indian Peaks.

* WHEN...From noon Wednesday to midnight MST Thursday night.

* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. Areas of blowing
snow could significantly reduce visibility. The hazardous
conditions could impact the morning or evening commute. Strong
winds could cause tree damage. The cold wind chills as low as
20 below zero could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as
little as 30 minutes.
properties.instruction:
Slow down and use caution while traveling.

The latest road conditions for the state you are calling from can
be obtained by calling 5 1 1.

NWSheadline: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM NOON WEDNESDAY TO MIDNIGHT MST THURSDAY NIGHT
